likes: Seek automation of development workflows that speed up time to delivery without hassle.
Tend toward scientific and engineering pursuits with a structured problem-solving mindset.
Vary in choice of operating system but more likely to be on macOS or linux.
Seek to build new skills with technology trends and approaches to increase future job prospects or for use on future projects.
Prefer clear and helpful documentation is key to success, though would prefer to not have to read it when technology is intuitive to use.
Will trust peer recommendations over vendor claims.
Seek the existence of a vibrant community is an indicator of technology that will remain longer term.
Tend to be playful and participate in internet pop culture with a sci-fi or fantasy influences (stereotype).
Want control over their destiny, so transparency is preferred over black-box solutions that do not provide an escape hatch should a new requirement emerge.
dislikes: Distrust sensational claims using language that is perceived as empty or markety making sensational hyperbolic statements using business jargon.
Skip White papers or other gated content that requires signing up for spam email when motivated to learn something new.
Avoid repetitive tasks that lack mental stimulation.
Will identify errors in documentation or code samples and is a common pet peeve that leads to a lack of trust of the product overall.
Dislike adding complexity (that they don't build themselves), slowing performance, introducing risk of on-time delivery, or other unreliable behavior
Are wary of a lack of community activity, unresolved/unresponded tickets, etc. will discourage from use of tools from that community.
Despise wasting time on frivilous or tasks that are deemed not worth mental energy. Would rather solve interesting problems than file paperwork.

design: Through simplicity and elegance of functional purpose.
product: With troubleshooting guides for any difficult to understand or new features earn trust that team knows and is working on it.
Through self-service and product-led-growth tactics that allow them to experiment and learn immediately on day 1 rather than waiting for a meeting to enable access.
Get to a wow moment quickly since they may be evaluating multiple alternatives with a finite amount of time for onboarding.
education: Base content on learning modality with types of educational content in tutorials, reference, etc.
Share technical details to prove a claim is valid. Focus is on the how for learning and will often match that tool to various whys themselves.
Onboard with a checklist that can be given to developers can go a long way to showing them a path.
communications: Communicate to devs with direct and concise messages rather than overly verbose communication styles.
sales: Appeal to laziness as a common virtue of developers who will appreciate logic on how a problem is less busy work for them.
Accept they will rigorously evaluate and want to kick the tires for themselves first before considering for adoption.
Acknowledge repeated attempts will be met with dismay as they may want to self-service initially before engaging with meetings
Let them evaluate, if only path is through sales they will prioritize competitors who let them start right away first or to consider open-source alternatives.
When they have success so they can stop their search for a solution.
Cllaborate with a technical resource like a solutions engineer or developer advocate to be able to address any technical questions or objections when engaging.
Sell to devs through transparency and predictably, they often don't want to negotiate and will pay sticker price.
marketing: Market to devs with care because they are a skeptical audience for any claims and language that sound like sensational hyperbole.
Market to devs through flexibility, speed and performance, or customization because of frequent requirements changes in their role favor adaptability.
Market to devs by avoiding buzzwords and try to use appropriate terminology that remove ambiguity
Market to devs by sharing how something is made, behind the scenes, which earns respect for the value of a solution. That helps convince a developer to use rather than build it themselves.
Market to devs after first engaging in non-threatening, non-sales types of events. Educational content and fun community social experiences can make the relationship more comfortable first.
